pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw: We should probably use the same ign-common version for all ignition libraries for Dome. So this means bumping to common4 for other libraries like ign-rendering, ign-sensors, ign-gui, etc. @{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} ?
content.html: We should probably use the same ign-common version for all ignition libraries for Dome. So this means bumping to common4 for other libraries like ign-rendering, ign-sensors, ign-gui, etc. @Louise Poubel ?

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw:
Yup, we can only have one version of each library per distribution, otherwise things can get too messy.

It feels a bit overkill to bump basically the entire stack just for that protected member variable though. If there's no way around it, it would be *great* to at least take the opportunity to pimpl that class too.
content.html:
Yup, we can only have one version of each library per distribution, otherwise things can get too messy.

It feels a bit overkill to bump basically the entire stack just for that protected member variable though. If there's no way around it, it would be great to at least take the opportunity to pimpl that class too.

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw:
I agree on changing the class to pimpl, I can do that and update the PR but I also agree that even with that change it is quite overkill to bump the whole stack.

While this is a “nice to have” fix since the interpolate\_x tag is basically broken we can put this on hold and see how the Dome development progresses on, if we reach a critical mass of API / ABI breaking changes on ign-common then we can push this and bump all the other packages?
content.html:
I agree on changing the class to pimpl, I can do that and update the PR but I also agree that even with that change it is quite overkill to bump the whole stack.

While this is a “nice to have” fix since the interpolate_x tag is basically broken we can put this on hold and see how the Dome development progresses on, if we reach a critical mass of API / ABI breaking changes on ign-common then we can push this and bump all the other packages?

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw:
An ugly hack around the ABI break would be to store the new member in a static map [like this](https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B#Adding_new_data_members_to_classes_without_d-pointer).

If this isn't urgent to get in, I second your option of waiting to see if we need more API breakages though.
content.html:
An ugly hack around the ABI break would be to store the new member in a static map like this.

If this isn't urgent to get in, I second your option of waiting to see if we need more API breakages though.

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw: \+1 we could use the hack to get this in to ign-common3 if it’s needed for the project, otherwise it would be good to use this opportunity to update the class to pimpl
content.html: +1 we could use the hack to get this in to ign-common3 if it’s needed for the project, otherwise it would be good to use this opportunity to update the class to pimpl

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw:
I found out that the hardcoded distance threshold was to prevent the `PoseAtX` function from going into an infinite loop for animations that do not move in x, e.g. person standing animation in `actor.sdf` so I added some checks back. I also fixed a problem with actors that have multiple animations from the same dae file, which was likely introduced in pull request #579.

[61fbd5b](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/61fbd5b3c6c94b4702f32255c83b3a5f3d845658)
content.html:
I found out that the hardcoded distance threshold was to prevent the PoseAtX function from going into an infinite loop for animations that do not move in x, e.g. person standing animation in actor.sdf so I added some checks back. I also fixed a problem with actors that have multiple animations from the same dae file, which was likely introduced in pull request #579.

61fbd5b

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw:
Yea was looking at that, the infinite loop is the issue I was trying to fix in the first place with this PR, it only happens if the user sets InterpolateX\(\) to true and the actor doesn’t move and it might be argued that if they do there is something logically wrong with the sdf \(they are asking “please interpolate the animation based on x displacement” but the x displacement is 0 in the first place\).

I do agree that wrong behavior is better than infinite loop in that case, but maybe we should still notify the user that something fishy is happening?

\[Edit\] I’m also a bit worried about arbitrary thresholds, i.e. 0.1 before or the tolerance for math::equal now, what will happen if the distance “oscillates” around 0, for example because the center of mass at the hip is moving while walking?
content.html:
Yea was looking at that, the infinite loop is the issue I was trying to fix in the first place with this PR, it only happens if the user sets InterpolateX() to true and the actor doesn’t move and it might be argued that if they do there is something logically wrong with the sdf (they are asking “please interpolate the animation based on x displacement” but the x displacement is 0 in the first place).

I do agree that wrong behavior is better than infinite loop in that case, but maybe we should still notify the user that something fishy is happening?

[Edit] I’m also a bit worried about arbitrary thresholds, i.e. 0.1 before or the tolerance for math::equal now, what will happen if the distance “oscillates” around 0, for example because the center of mass at the hip is moving while walking?

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw: yeah with the new changes, the `<interpolate_x>` should be respected except the case when there is no x displacement to interpolate. We can add a warning message when that happens.
content.html: yeah with the new changes, the <interpolate_x> should be respected except the case when there is no x displacement to interpolate. We can add a warning message when that happens.

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw:
added warning msgs in [2f7a2e7](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/2f7a2e7304583b342e5c807a5347cf5a64b1903b).  Now it prints a few msgs when running `actor.sdf`, e.g.

```
[Wrn] [SceneManager.cc:711] Animation has no x displacement. Ignoring <interpolate_x> for animation in 'file:///home/osrf/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/stand.dae'
```

I’m on the fence about whether or not to include them or not. It requires the user to have prior knowledge of the animation data in the mesh. I think typical robotics developers aren’t the ones creating the animations so they won’t know until they try them out in simulation. I’ll leave that to you @{557058:798a6cdf-d171-444d-b8af-5d088f9feb2d}  to decide if we should include the warnings or not.
content.html:
added warning msgs in 2f7a2e7. Now it prints a few msgs when running actor.sdf, e.g.

[Wrn] [SceneManager.cc:711] Animation has no x displacement. Ignoring <interpolate_x> for animation in 'file:///home/osrf/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/stand.dae'

I’m on the fence about whether or not to include them or not. It requires the user to have prior knowledge of the animation data in the mesh. I think typical robotics developers aren’t the ones creating the animations so they won’t know until they try them out in simulation. I’ll leave that to you @Luca Della Vedova to decide if we should include the warnings or not.

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw:
I’m also not 100% sure, from one side I think it makes sense that if we are explicitly ignoring a parameter that was set in the sdf because the mesh doesn’t support it we at least inform the user we are doing it. The implementation however is not very pretty but I don’t think that can be helped.  
I’m a “weak yes”, would fix the typo in [690](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/2f7a2e7304583b342e5c807a5347cf5a64b1903b/src/rendering/SceneManager.cc#lines-690) and probably set the set to an unordered\_set in [693](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/2f7a2e7304583b342e5c807a5347cf5a64b1903b/src/rendering/SceneManager.cc#lines-693).
content.html:
I’m also not 100% sure, from one side I think it makes sense that if we are explicitly ignoring a parameter that was set in the sdf because the mesh doesn’t support it we at least inform the user we are doing it. The implementation however is not very pretty but I don’t think that can be helped.
I’m a “weak yes”, would fix the typo in 690 and probably set the set to an unordered_set in 693.

content.html: +1 to unordered_set - mind making the change, @Luca Della Vedova ? Then I think we're ready to merge. Thanks!

pullrequest.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

content.raw: Another thing to point out is that manual copying here is fragile. If new fields are added to the `SkeletonAnimation` class, we'll probably forget to copy them here. Maybe adding a copy constructor / operator to that class would also be handy - in the future.
content.html: Another thing to point out is that manual copying here is fragile. If new fields are added to the SkeletonAnimation class, we'll probably forget to copy them here. Maybe adding a copy constructor / operator to that class would also be handy - in the future.

I see Mingfei's included actor also triggers this. I think we should probably copy that actor to the openrobotics account and fix it there.
